title: HELP.Can I file bankruptcy I owe between $13000 to $15000 to the IRS from 06-07-08. I did file my taxes .
question: I owe between $13000 to $15000 to the IRS from 06-07-08. I did file my taxes and that's what I owe. My company went under in the course of those 2 yrs. I cannot pay. I'm now unemployed and haven't been able to get back on feet. can I file bankruptcy? If so can I file bankruptcy for other bills I have for ex I owe $11000 to Toll roads for having my transponder in my car but never registering my car in my express toll road acct plus about $10000 in credit cards?? please help. I'm sinking n depression from not being able to fix this.
question_tags: Small business taxes,Debt collection for businesses,Chapter 7 bankruptcy for businesses,Chapter 13 bankruptcy for businesses,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Priority debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Business,Tax law
answers:
You will need a service, like the one linked below, to review your IRS transcripts to determine if your income taxes can be eliminated in bankruptcy. Older taxes can be eliminated in bankruptcy, but the tax debt must satisfy several rules and not fall into any exceptions to those rules.

As for the rest, bankruptcy is generally the most comprehensive solution to a person's debt.

Making the decision whether or not you can qualify to file one of the three types of bankruptcy cases that are available requires a lot more information than you can post in an online forum. Bankruptcy laws do require you to include all your debts, even those you want to pay, such as a vehicle loan, and those you can't avoid paying, such as a priority debt. While it appears that your IRS debt could be eliminated in bankruptcy, you haven't provided enough information for me to be able to say with absolute certainty that you can eliminate this debt in a Chapter 7. You must also show that you qualify financially for any form of bankruptcy that you file. Bottom line - making this decision is complicated, and really requires an in person consultation. Hope this perspective helps!

Old taxes can often be discharged in a Chapter 7 or Chapter 13. This being said you need to consult with a BK lawyer and get transcripts from the IRS. Certain taxes are not dischargeble such as employee withholding. And, there are other. As to the toll road charges they are dischargeable i a Chapter 13 but not in a Chapter 7. Don't let depression keep you from getting an experience lawyer from analyzing your problem.

The general rules are if the taxes have been due four least three years, actually filed for two and assessed more than 240 days. You can contact the IRS and get your Record of the Account for the years at issue to make this determination. I do suggest you contact the lawyer. My firm will be happy to review your records for you. Without making any type a guarantee, from what you have stated there appears to be a good likelihood that your 1040 taxes could be discharged in a chapter seven bankruptcy.
